quotes.topic_title: Introduction and background on growth misinformation
quotes.text: Oftentimes things that are completely out of context or they are very specific to one example and actually do not apply as a pattern.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A warning to treat viral “growth hacks” as non-transferable unless you can prove the underlying pattern fits your context.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and background on growth misinformation
quotes.text: There is a huge misconception in the field that in order to get growth going, you need a growth team. To figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it, it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrarian guidance that PMF and distribution are core company responsibilities, not something a newly formed growth team can “own” into existence.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and background on growth misinformation
quotes.text: Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of UK marketing site produce good performance results.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A strong claim practitioners can use to challenge roadmap items that promise acquisition gains from cosmetic brand/site changes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and background on growth misinformation
quotes.text: Number three, if every single one of your initiatives that you're doing on growth is an experiment that's a problem. It's almost like a disease, like a paralyzing disease.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A mental model for diagnosing “experiment theater” where teams hide behind testing instead of committing to bigger bets and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and background on growth misinformation
quotes.text: And my north star metric is insights per minute.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical personal/team operating metric to optimize meetings and decision-making for learning velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #1: Hiring growth too early
quotes.text: In order to get the growth going in the company, a founder and the founding team have to figure out how to make it grow to the first, let's say a million, 5 million, 10 million in ARR.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets a clear founder-led growth milestone framework before hiring a dedicated growth team.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #1: Hiring growth too early
quotes.text: Some of the companies don't even create growth teams until they're a hundred, 200 million in ARR because to figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contradicts the common belief that hiring growth early is necessary, emphasizing PMF and distribution as non-outsourcable.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #1: Hiring growth too early
quotes.text: I really believe that the founder led growth is not being popularized enough that you do not need growth teams until you actually can start running experiments on your user base, which means that you have volume of users that you can learn from and optimize and innovate on, and that first wave of growth has to be founder led.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides an experimentation/volume threshold as the gating condition for when a growth team becomes useful.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #1: Hiring growth too early
quotes.text: If you have 10 users or 10 customers, that's not data, that's a G-sheet with your customers and you don't need a growth team for that.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Memorable heuristic for why early-stage “growth” is usually just hands-on customer work, not scalable experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #1: Hiring growth too early
quotes.text: Yes. And honestly, the longer you wait, the better it is because that way your entire company will be trained to be responsible for growth as opposed to putting this one island with a growth team and saying, "They're going to be growing," and what is the rest of the company doing? Honestly, the longer you wait, the better.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Argues delaying a growth hire builds a company-wide growth mindset instead of isolating growth responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sales-led vs product-led timing for growth hires
quotes.text: It depends on how you're actually going to collect the monies. If your money collection is going to happen through sales team primarily, then you absolutely should be hiring sales way before growth.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for sequencing sales vs growth hires based on the primary monetization motion.

quotes.topic_title: Sales-led vs product-led timing for growth hires
quotes.text: In fact, in the sales led companies, growth teams are not necessarily needed even that much.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that challenges the default assumption that every scaling company needs a growth team early.

quotes.topic_title: Sales-led vs product-led timing for growth hires
quotes.text: You're trying to have product sell itself through potentially freemium acquisition, trial acquisition or you actually having product led activation, monetization, that's when you would need a growth person.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clarifies the trigger condition for hiring growth: when the product owns key funnel steps like activation and monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Sales-led vs product-led timing for growth hires
quotes.text: If you're starting with self-serve monetization, growth hire should be frankly first before sales.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A strong, actionable hiring priority that flips the common “sales first” playbook for self-serve businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Sales-led vs product-led timing for growth hires
quotes.text: If you have any product-led components where product is responsible for acquisition, activation, monetization or retention, that's where growth comes in.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical checklist for when growth becomes necessary: whenever product takes responsibility for any major funnel lever.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: That just does not happen. If you have the overall business slowing down, your head of growth is destined to fail because the reason business is slowing down is much deeper than not having a growth team.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that hiring a growth leader won’t fix underlying product/GTM causes of decline.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: Growth team can optimize, growth can maybe lift it by 10, 15%. Maybe that's enough for you. Even that is on the upper end of what growth team will be able to do if there is a slow-down trajectory.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations for what growth can achieve during a slowdown (incremental, not transformational).

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: You're going to have to address the big elephant in the room as to why business is slowing down in the first place as opposed to just plopping a growth team on the issue and expecting them to do miracles while the rest of the business continues chugging on the same trajectory that caused the slowdown in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: diagnose and fix root causes before expecting growth tactics to work.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: But if you are slowing down and you have issues with either your go-to-market strategy or your core product strategy with your core product market fit, growth is going to be absolutely helpless to do anything.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Clear mental model: growth amplifies PMF, but cannot compensate for degraded PMF or broken GTM/product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #2: Hiring growth to reverse decline
quotes.text: If you are declining in your revenue growth or whatever other metric that you're looking at, your weekly active users or whatnot, see at least that you're able to plateau it so you can stop the decline.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Practical hiring heuristic: don’t hire growth to reverse decline—hire after you’ve stabilized metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #3: Rebrands and homepage redesigns for growth
quotes.text: Every single time I've seen a marketing site at least rebrand, it's been a step back in performance that then is being treated as a fire drill to fix. Just don't do it if you expect immediate results out of it, or at least educate the team on how long it's going to take to get to the point where you think that there's going to be upside away from your original brand.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Sets an expectation-management rule: rebrands typically cause an initial dip and require planned recovery time.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #3: Rebrands and homepage redesigns for growth
quotes.text: But to ever promise a homepage redesign or marketing site redesign in order to drive more acquisition is a failed promise that is going to be led by lots of agency money spending, often a million dollars plus, lots of arguing about which shade of blue your brand color is going to be, and eight to 10 months at the minimum of development and very lackluster results afterwards.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that redesigns are commonly oversold as growth levers despite high cost, long timelines, and weak outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #3: Rebrands and homepage redesigns for growth
quotes.text: It's a new starting point and that starting point is going to be much lower than your current optimized experience that you have. Whether it's well optimized or not optimized, it doesn't matter. It's gone through some level of optimization versus rebrand is always a shot in the dark. It might be prettier, sure, but that doesn't mean it's going to perform well.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A mental model for redesign risk: you reset to a lower baseline because you discard accumulated optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #3: Rebrands and homepage redesigns for growth
quotes.text: The goal here should be, we will launch, we will probably see a hit, model out and forecast for a hit, and then give yourself two to three months at the minimum, ideally more like six months, to really optimize it back to a good standing where it can potentially outperform.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Provides an actionable planning methodology: forecast the post-launch dip and budget 3–6 months of optimization work.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #3: Rebrands and homepage redesigns for growth
quotes.text: The best I've ever seen is that it produced net neutral results and it produced us better ability to optimize towards something bigger. That's the best case scenario.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes “success” for rebrands as enabling future optimization rather than immediate growth impact.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #4: Copying competitors and misusing benchmarks
quotes.text: That's where things really go wrong because every single experience is very unique to their customer, to their channel.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A reminder that competitor flows don’t transfer cleanly because product context (customer + channel) fundamentally shapes what works.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #4: Copying competitors and misusing benchmarks
quotes.text: And there's a lot of drive, especially to have it as a shortcut. "Okay, we don't want to go through this ideation or user research. We don't want to do user interviews, but we don't want to do A/B testing. It works for them. It must work for us. Let's just go and do it." And it fails 95% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete warning (with a striking failure rate) against using competitor copying as a substitute for research and experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #4: Copying competitors and misusing benchmarks
quotes.text: And you can take those elements and put them into your product, but you can never skip the ideation, the design, the user research, the customer interview, the experimentation step.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical methodology: extract reusable elements/patterns, but still run the full discovery-to-experimentation process.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #4: Copying competitors and misusing benchmarks
quotes.text: Because copying competition is like the fastest way to mediocrity because you'll never be a leader if you copied somebody else.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes copying as an anti-strategy for differentiation and category leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #4: Copying competitors and misusing benchmarks
quotes.text: Benchmarks are also very dangerous here to use because benchmarks are usually done on all of the competition, on all of the softwares out there. And the way people define numbers is so different from company to company.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable caution that benchmark comparisons often break due to inconsistent metric definitions across companies and tools.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #5: Treating problems as unique (starting from scratch)
quotes.text: I'm very sorry to break it to all of you, but your problem is not unique. I am 99% sure of that. Your problem has been felt by somebody somewhere in probably many, many places and you trying to re-engineer solution is time lost to market and has a huge opportunity cost.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that reinventing solutions is usually an avoidable opportunity cost because most growth problems are common.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #5: Treating problems as unique (starting from scratch)
quotes.text: And number one thing that whenever you have an initiative or whenever you have a metric that you need to go and move, to not start from scratch, ever. Do not start from scratch. It's the worst thing that you can do because you can waste so many cycles on trying to do something that probably has already been solved, which means how do you approach this as a result?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice to default to reuse and learning rather than building bespoke approaches for each metric/initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #5: Treating problems as unique (starting from scratch)
quotes.text: You should go find people that have solved this problem because there are people there and people love to talk about what they do. So take advantage of that human psychology and go find those people and just ask them, "How did you do it? What did you do? What happened?"
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical methodology: treat expert outreach as a repeatable shortcut to proven solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #5: Treating problems as unique (starting from scratch)
quotes.text: Make patterns. Make patterns out of your solutions. So more you can stop looking at as a unique data point or unique problem and more as there is, I need to fit it into existing pattern or I need to figure out the framework on how to solve not only this problem but other problems. The faster you'll be able to get at least to like 60% of the solution there.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A reusable mental model: patternize solutions to get quickly to a solid baseline before customizing implementation.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #5: Treating problems as unique (starting from scratch)
quotes.text: And she's like, "Well, are you talking about a user community or an agency community or a partner community?" And I'm like, my mind was blown. I'm like, "I even considering all of these angles because I was just literally thinking about users only." And she's like, "Well, you shouldn't necessarily start with the user community. If you want some results out of it, go to agency or partner communities first."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete example of how talking to experienced operators can reframe the problem and reveal higher-leverage starting points.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yes, so we just launched OneSchema file feeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A concrete, time-bound methodology for rapidly shipping integrations via a simple CSV-to-SFTP constraint.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We allow our customers to offer thousands of integrations without involving their engineering team at all.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable operating model: decouple integration breadth from engineering bandwidth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of multi-day outages from even just a handful of ad records.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A vivid example of how small data issues can cascade into major reliability incidents, motivating preventative controls.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system, and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: Actionable reliability practice: validate at the boundary and alert quickly to prevent downstream damage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wait longer than you think to hire a head of growth. Wait until you have product market fit, maybe a million, or especially if you're self-serve oriented.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring guidance that ties growth leadership timing to PMF and scale thresholds.

quotes.topic_title: Recap of tactics one through five
quotes.text: So the first is, wait longer than you think to hire a head of growth. Wait until you have product market fit, maybe a million, or especially if you're self-serve oriented.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring guidance: delay bringing in growth leadership until PMF and sufficient scale, especially for self-serve products.

quotes.topic_title: Recap of tactics one through five
quotes.text: Number two is if your growth is declining, the head of growth won't solve that problem. First, stop the decline at least.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Practical triage model: stabilize a declining growth system before expecting a growth leader to drive improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Recap of tactics one through five
quotes.text: Rebranding is not only not going to help you grow, it's going to probably hurt growth and slow things down. And so just go into that wide eyes wide open.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Challenges a common default tactic by warning that rebrands often create drag and can reduce growth rather than increase it.

quotes.topic_title: Recap of tactics one through five
quotes.text: These things are a lot more patternized than you would expect them to be, so go and find those patterns as opposed to trying to re-engineer it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A reusable methodology for growth work: treat activation/monetization issues as recognizable patterns and learn from existing solutions instead of reinventing.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #6: Growth teams over-prioritizing SEO/SEM
quotes.text: However, as a growth team, your number one priority is to create your own or your earned channel. So channel that you've earned and that nobody else can compete in but you.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes growth team priorities away from rented distribution toward defensible, owned/earned acquisition loops.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #6: Growth teams over-prioritizing SEO/SEM
quotes.text: An algorithm can giveth, but algorithm can also taketh away at any point. And you have no control because you don't own those channels.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable warning about the fragility of SEO/SEM/social when platform rules and ranking systems change.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #6: Growth teams over-prioritizing SEO/SEM
quotes.text: Referrals from people to people are everything.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concise directive to prioritize word-of-mouth/referral mechanics as a primary acquisition lever.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #6: Growth teams over-prioritizing SEO/SEM
quotes.text: It's not cheapest. It's actually cost a lot of product and engineering and even marketing resources to stand up. So it's not the cost of a budget, but it's cost of people that will have to work to create your own channel, so to speak, for acquisition.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counters the common belief that virality/PLG is “free,” clarifying the real resourcing model required to build owned channels.

quotes.topic_title: Tactic #6: Growth teams over-prioritizing SEO/SEM
quotes.text: But if you are not exploring it and if you are not investing into it or at least trying and failing within it, I think that you are really leaving too much of your growth future into the hands of somebody else that you have low control over.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable push to run experiments and invest in earned channels to reduce dependency risk on external platforms.
